title: Carotid Artery Stenosis with TIA
diagnosis_topic: Symptomatic carotid stenosis causing transient ischemic attack
setup_script: A 68-year-old woman reports sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech lasting 30 minutes, which resolved spontaneously. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia and a 40-pack-year smoking history. She presents for evaluation.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 150/85 mmHg, HR 78 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.7 C.
Normal strength and sensation now; carotid bruit present on right.
Carotid duplex shows 80% stenosis of right internal carotid artery; CT brain no acute infarct.
CBC and BMP unremarkable, LDL 160 mg/dL.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates antiplatelet therapy and statin

dynamic_flow.reply: Discuss carotid endarterectomy vs. stenting given symptomatic high-grade stenosis.
Patient develops another TIA with persistent deficits.
Carotid intervention ideally within 2 weeks of TIA for symptomatic patients.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about perioperative stroke risk
dynamic_flow.reply: Evaluate cardiac status, continue antiplatelets; control blood pressure.
Recognize risk of cranial nerve injury and hematoma; plan sedation vs. general anesthesia.
Smoking, hypertension, diabetes and hyperlipidemia; counsel on cessation.
Postoperative duplex at 1 month, then annually to monitor for restenosis.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of symptomatic carotid stenosis as indication for intervention
Initiation of best medical therapy while awaiting surgery
Timely referral for carotid endarterectomy vs. stenting
Counseling on risk factors and postoperative surveillance
